note.title: Badge URLs Must Use Placeholders
note.content: README badges (PyPI, coverage, license, Python versions) should use shields.io URLs with placeholders since package is not yet published to PyPI. Use format: https://img.shields.io/badge/... or https://img.shields.io/pypi/v/temporalio-graphs (will work once published).

note.title: API Reference Organization
note.content: API reference can be created as separate docs/api-reference.md file OR as section in README. Tech spec suggests separate file for cleaner organization. Include: analyze_workflow(), GraphBuildingContext, to_decision(), wait_condition(), exception hierarchy. Extract from existing docstrings rather than rewriting.

note.title: CHANGELOG Content Strategy
note.content: CHANGELOG.md should document features from Epics 1-5 in [0.1.0] section. Group by category (Added, Changed, etc.) per Keep a Changelog format. Use epic summaries from docs/epics.md as source material. Include [Unreleased] section for future changes.

note.title: .NET Comparison Requires Spike Reference
note.content: Architecture differences section (AC7) should reference spike/EXECUTIVE_SUMMARY.md which explains why Python uses static analysis vs .NET's runtime interceptors. Key points: Python SDK interceptor limitations, performance benefits (sub-millisecond), no execution required. Create comparison table showing feature parity.

note.title: Troubleshooting Examples Must Be Realistic
note.content: Troubleshooting guide (AC8) should use realistic error scenarios from exception classes. Each error should show: error message format, root cause, step-by-step solution, code example. Reference exceptions.py for actual error message formats to ensure accuracy.

note.title: Configuration Patterns Should Show Use Cases
note.content: Configuration patterns section (AC3) should not just list GraphBuildingContext fields but show realistic use cases: "Disable word splitting for acronyms", "Custom domain terminology", "Complex workflows with many decisions", "File output for CI/CD", etc. Current README has good examples to build on.

note.title: Core Concepts Should Use Visual Diagrams
note.content: Core concepts section (AC2) should include visual elements where helpful: Mermaid diagram showing all node types (activity rectangle, decision diamond, signal hexagon), path permutation tree showing 2^n explosion, etc. These diagrams make concepts clearer than text alone.

note.title: Contributing Guidelines Scope
note.content: Contributing section (AC1) can be brief for MVP - link to GitHub issues, mention code quality standards (mypy, ruff, pytest), reference IMPLEMENTATION_PLAN.md for current priorities. Full CONTRIBUTING.md file is post-MVP scope.

note.title: Documentation Tone Guidance
note.content: Tech spec requires "professional tone without being overly formal" and "clear and accessible to intermediate Python developers". Use technical accuracy but approachable language. Avoid jargon without explanation. Use examples liberally. Current README tone is good reference.
